item.title: Hardware
item.description:
Hardware

- ## Cables & Connectors
	- ## Network Cables
		- ### Description
			- A medium through which data is transferred from one device to another.
			- ### There are Three primary types of network cables #card
		- ### Copper Medium #card
			- The most common medium used in both coaxial and twisted pair cables.
		- ### Cat
		  
			- Categories, also referred to as Cat, describes the performance of twisted pair cables.
			- All Cat cables 2 through 8 are composed of four pairs of twisted-pairs totaling eight individual cables in one cable sheath.
			- Cat 5 #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:33:55.736Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:33:55.736Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
			  
				- 100 Mbps
				- 100 meter max distance
			- Cat 5e #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:32:23.735Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:32:23.736Z
			  card-last-score:: 3
			  
				- 1 Gbps
				- 100 meter max distance
				- Increased speed due to the separated twisted pairs and increased number of twists.
			- Cat 6 #card
			  card-last-interval:: -1
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.5
			  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-29T05:00:00.000Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:31:49.355Z
			  card-last-score:: 1
			  
				- 10 Gbps
				- 55 meters max distance
			- Cat 6a #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 2
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:36:45.217Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:36:45.218Z
			  card-last-score:: 3
			  
				- 10 Gbps
				- 100 meters max distance
		- ### Coaxial
		  
			- ### What is a coaxial cable? #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:43:28.420Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:43:28.421Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
				- A single copper-cored cable contained in an inner insulation layer.
				- Then it is surrounded by a wire mesh conductor.
				- Finally it is enclosed in an outer insulation layer.
			- Where are Coaxial cables used? #card
			  card-last-interval:: -1
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.5
			  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-29T05:00:00.000Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:32:06.794Z
			  card-last-score:: 1
			  
				- Mostly used in cable and satellite devices.
				- Not as commonly used in modern networks.
			- What specifies the Coaxial Cables? #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:32:13.031Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:32:13.032Z
			  card-last-score:: 3
			  
				- Radio Guide (RG) system
			- What two cables do you need to know? #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:33:31.250Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:33:31.250Z
			  card-last-score:: 3
			  
				- RG-59
				  
					- Thinner gauge cable
					- low bandwidth and low frequency
					- Used in cable TV
				- RG-6
				  
					- Heavier gauge
					- High-bandwidth and high-frequency applications
					- Used in satellites and cable modems
		- ### Twisted Copper Pair
		  
			- What is a twisted copper pair? #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:47:30.221Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:47:30.221Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
				- Individual wires twisted into pairs and then twisted with other pairs
			- Are Ethernet cables twisted pair? #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:34:20.226Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:34:20.226Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
			  
				- YES
			- Twisted Copper Pair Types#card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:31:41.372Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:31:41.374Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
			  
				- Shielded twisted pair (STP)
				- Unshielded twisted pair (UTP)
				- Typically in configurations of two or four
			- Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP) #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:36:34.893Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:36:34.894Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
			  
				- A cable that doesn't have any foil shielding around it.
				- Doesn't protect against EMI
			- Shielded Twisted Pair (STP) #card
			  card-last-interval:: 4
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
			  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:34:28.817Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:34:28.818Z
			  card-last-score:: 5
			  
				- A cable surrounded by a braided foil sheathing which prevents EMI
				- Used in Cat 7 and Cat 8 cables
			- Twisted Pair Color Code #card
			  card-last-interval:: -1
			  card-repeats:: 1
			  card-ease-factor:: 2.5
			  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-29T05:00:00.000Z
			  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:36:14.435Z
			  card-last-score:: 1
			  
				- T568A Standard
					- Green/white, green, orange/white, blue, blue/white, orange, brown/white, brown
				- T568B Standard
					- Orange/white, orange, green/white, blue, blue/white, green, brown/white, brown
		- ### Direct burial #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:33:42.034Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:33:42.034Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- The practice of burying cables underground
		- ### Direct burial best practices #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:48:09.731Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:48:09.731Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Cables should be STP and have an extra waterproof sheathing
			- Burial between six and eight inches underground in protective PVC pipe and placed away from other lines containing electrical current
		- ### Plenum #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:47:37.756Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:47:37.756Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- A Teflon-type covering used to cover all types of network cables
			- Doesn't release harmful gasses when exposed to extreme heat
			- Used in ceilings ,where air is circulated, or tight spaces
		- ### Optical #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:36:20.685Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:36:20.686Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- The transmission method that depends on light pulses for data transfer
		- ### Fiber #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:33:52.845Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:33:52.846Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- Small strings of flexible glass that are used in optical data transmission
		- ### Fiber Optic Cables #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:34:15.254Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:34:15.255Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- A fiber surrounded by a rubberized coating and provides speeds from 100 Mbps to 10 Gbps over a max distance of several miles
			- Immune to both electrical interference and wiretapping
			  
				- NOTE: There are ways to wiretap fiber
		- ### Single-mode Fiber #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:34:33.924Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:34:33.924Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- Carries only one light path
			- Typically sourced by a laser
			- Very long transmission distance
		- ### Multimode Fiber #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:36:26.783Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:36:26.784Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- Carries multiple light paths and is sourced by an LED
			- Shorter Transmission distance than single-mode fiber
	- ## Peripheral Cables
	  
		- What are peripheral cables? #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:40:51.183Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:51.184Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
			- Cables that attach peripheral devices to computing devices
			- i.e
			- printers, keyboards, monitors, and USB devices
		- USB 2.0 #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 2
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:45:09.307Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:45:09.308Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Max speed of 480 Mbps
			- Referred to as Hi-speed
		- USB 3.0 #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:40:17.763Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:17.763Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Max Speed of 5 Gbps
			- Referred to as Super Speed
		- Serial Cable#card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:39:00.517Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:39:00.517Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- Used for serial communications with a corresponding serial connector on the end
			- DB9 is the most common serial connection type and has <ins>nine pins</ins> .
		- Thunderbolt #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:44:03.606Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:44:03.607Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- A combination of PCI Express 2.0 x4 and DisplayPort 1.x tech
			- Made primarily for video transmission but can be used for other peripheral devices
			- There are 4 standards
				- Thunderbolt 1 and 2 terminate in Mini-DisplayPort
				- Thunderbolt 3 and 4 terminate in USB-C
	- ## Video Cables
	  
		- Designed to transmit data to visual display units
		- ### High-definition multimedia interface (HDMI) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:41:46.765Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:41:46.766Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Has 19 pins
			- Developed to transmit high frame rates and digital audio on a single cable
		- ### DisplayPort (DP) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:38:45.091Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:38:45.092Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- Developed to use less power than previous video cables
			- Backward compatible with VGA and DVI
			- Standard cables have two hooks to lock it in place
		- ### Digital visual interface (DVI) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:41:57.180Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:41:57.181Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Addresses the shortcomings of analog video transmission
			- Can transmit digital video signals to display units
			- Typically white cables
		- ### DVI connector standards #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:42:38.167Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:42:38.168Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- DVI-A: Analog connection only
			- DVI-D: Digital connection only
			- DVI-I: For both digital and analog signals
		- Video graphics array (VGA) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:38:13.363Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:38:13.364Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- The oldest video standard still in use today
			- Strictly analog
			- Typically a blue color
	- ## Hard Drive Cables
	  
		- ### Hard Drive Connections #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:37:44.927Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:37:44.928Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
			- known as drive interfaces
			- either on or off-board
			- The interface is based on the hard drives requirements
			- Consists of circuitry and a header, or port
		- ### Serial Advanced Technology Attachment (SATA) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:46:09.987Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:46:09.987Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- The most common drive interface
			- A flat terminating connector that can only plug in one way
			- Data cables have seven pins
			- Power cables have 15 pins
		- ### Sata Speeds #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:40:26.284Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:26.285Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- 1.0 = 1.5 Gbps
			- 2.0 = 3 Gbps
			- 3.0 = 6 Gbps
			- 4.0 = 16 Gbps
		- ### Small Computer System Interface (SCSI) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:41:24.172Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:41:24.173Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Commonly used for storage device connections
			- Either ribon or round cables containing 50, 68, or 80 wires
			- Up to 16 devices, including the motherboard or SCSI controller card
			- Can be sing cable or daisy chained
		- ### External SATA (eSATA) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:39:18.887Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:39:18.887Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- External to the housing
			- Standard Cables are for data transmission only and do not provide power
			- eSATA that provides power is called Power over eSATA, eSATA+, eSATAp, or eSATA/USB
		- ### Integrated Drive Electronics (IDE) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:40:08.693Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:08.694Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Renamed parallel advanced technology attachment (PATA)
			- 40-pin flat data cables with a colored strip along one edge to indicate the location of pin 1
			- Three separate connectors on PATA cables, one for power and two for drives
	- ## Adapters #card
	  card-last-interval:: 4
	  card-repeats:: 1
	  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
	  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:46:02.618Z
	  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:46:02.618Z
	  card-last-score:: 5
	  
		- Converts one type of connection or cable technology to another
	- ## Connector Types
	  
		- Connectors are installed at the terminating points of cables to provide connection to compatible components and peripherals
		- depends on the cable
		- ### RJ11 #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-31T17:50:28.109Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-27T17:50:28.109Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Standard for telecommunication network interfaces
			- For voice and data equipment connections to a service provider or carrier
			- Twisted pair cables with four to six wires for connecting to traditional telephone lines of modems
		- ### RJ45 #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:39:47.497Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:39:47.499Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- A connector that receives 8 wires
			- Twisted pair cable with RJ45 connectors are referred to as Ethernet cables
		- ### F-type #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:42:01.387Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:42:01.388Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- used with coax cables and satellite data connetions
		- ### Straight Tip (ST) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:37:56.634Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:37:56.635Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- A bayonet style connector used with fiber optic cables
		- ### Subscriber connector (SC) #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:42:17.384Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:42:17.385Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- push/pull-style connector used with fiber optic cables
		- ### Lucent Connector (LC) #card
		  card-last-interval:: -1
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.5
		  card-next-schedule:: 2023-12-29T05:00:00.000Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:43.684Z
		  card-last-score:: 1
		  
			- Push/pull-style connector used with fiber optic cables
			- Half the size of an SC, making it suitable for office and data center usage
		- ### Punchdown Block #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:39:09.082Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:39:09.082Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- An electrical connection where multiple copper wires can be "punched down" or inserted into a slot
			- Provides insulation as well as electrical connection to attached wires
		- ### Micro USB #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:38:30.314Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:38:30.315Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- The smallest USB connector type
			- contains five pins
			- direction dependent
		- ### MiniUSB #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:42:25.313Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:42:25.314Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- Second smallest USB connector type
			- contains five pins
			- direction dependent
		- ### USB-C #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:40:33.229Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:33.229Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
			- Most recent USB connector type
			- Contains 24 pins
			- Oval shape
			- Reversible connection
		- ### Molex #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.36
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:45:02.480Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:45:02.481Z
		  card-last-score:: 3
		  
			- An older two-piece pin and socket interconnection type used for drive connections
		- ### Lighting Port #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:42:29.623Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:42:29.624Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- An eight-pin Apple proprietary connector
			- Reversible orientation
		- ### DB9 #card
		  card-last-interval:: 4
		  card-repeats:: 1
		  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
		  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T15:40:57.679Z
		  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T15:40:57.680Z
		  card-last-score:: 5
		  
			- Trapezoid shape
			- nine-pin connector
			- arranged in two rows of four and five pins
			- used for serial connections to network device consoles or management ports
- ## RAM
  
	- ### Random access memory (RAM) #card
	  card-last-interval:: 4
	  card-repeats:: 1
	  card-ease-factor:: 2.6
	  card-next-schedule:: 2024-01-01T18:54:15.442Z
	  card-last-reviewed:: 2023-12-28T18:54:15.443Z
	  card-last-score:: 5
		- A memory bank for data currently in use by a computer or device
		- RAM memory is temporary
		- Numerous types of RAM
	- ### Virtual RAM #card
	  card-last-interval:: 4
	  card-repeats:: 1
	  card-ease-factor:: 2.6

		- Laser printers create high-quality printouts using a complex process
		- The component that actually draws the image is a laser
		- It works with other components to transfer that image to the paper
		- #### Imaging Parts
			- Laser printers have the following specific imaging parts.
			- Imaging drumThe laser draws the page image onto the imaging drum.
			- Fuser assemblyThe fuser assembly applies pressure and heat to bond the toner to the paper.
			- Transfer BeltUsed in color laser printers, the transfer belt transfers the page image from the imaging drum to the paper.
			- Transfer rollerUsed in black-and-white laser printers, the transfer roller transfers the page image from the imaging drum to the paper.
			- Pickup rollersRubber pickup rollers feed paper from the paper tray through the printer.
			- Separation padsTo ensure that only one page is fed at a time, separation pads separate the page being fed from the pages underneath it.
			- Duplexing assemblyTo print on both sides of the paper, the duplexing assembly will flip the paper over.
		- #### Imaging Process
			- The imaging process of a laser printer specifies the process the printer follows to produce an image.
			- ProcessingBefore any actual printing is done, the image of the full page is placed into memory.
			- ChargingA high negative charge is applied to the imaging drum.
			- ExposingThe laser draws the image of the page onto the imaging drum by exposing it to the laser light
				- The tightly focused laser light removes the negative charge from the imaging drum (neutralizing it), leaving the rest of the drum negatively charged
			- DevelopingThe negatively charged toner is transferred to the imaging drum
				- Since the drum is also negatively charged, the toner will only stick to the areas that have been neutralized by the laser
			- TransferringThe transfer roller or transfer belt transfers the toner from the drum to the paper.
			- FusingA fusing roller uses heat and pressure to bond the toner to the paper.
			- CleaningAny residual toner is cleaned off of the imaging drum.
		- #### Maintenance
			- Laser printers tend to be expensive, so regular maintenance must be done to keep them running well for a long time
				- Manufacturers make this fairly easy for common maintenance tasks like replacing toner
				- Other tasks require more knowledge and skill
			- Replace tonerToner is used for each print job, so it must periodically be replaced
				- Toner comes in a toner cartridge that is easily replaced by the user.
			- Maintenance kitPrinter manufacturers recommend replacing certain parts periodically
				- They provide these parts in maintenance kits
				- They may include the fuser assembly, transfer belt, transfer roller, pickup rollers, and/or separate pads
			- CalibrateCalibration is done to keep the page image sharp and accurate
				- This may be done on a periodic basis and when parts are replaced
				- Each printer will have its own calibration process
			- CleanToner is a fine powder that will leave residue in the printer
				- Keeping the inside of the printer clean will keep it running well and prevent loose toner from showing up on printouts
	- ### Inkjet #card

		- Inkjet printers create high-quality printouts, though the resolution can be lessthan that of laser printers
		- They are also much less expensive
			- Several components work together to transfer the page image to the paper
		- They create the page image by spraying ink dots onto precise points on the paper
		  
		- #### Imaging Parts
			- Inkjet printers have the following specific imaging parts.
			- Ink cartridgeInk is stored in ink cartridges that supply ink to the print heads
			  
				- There may be a separate cartridge for each of the standard colors usedcyan, magenta, yellow, and black
				- Some inkjet printers use a combined color cartridge with cyan, magenta, and yellow ink, plus a black ink cartridge.
			- Print headThe print head draws the ink from the cartridge and ejects it onto the paper
				- Some printers combine the ink cartridge and the print head into a single unit
			- RollerPaper is fed through the printer by the roller.
			- FeederPaper may be fed from either a simple paper tray or a feeder
				- Most feeders have adjustments to allow you to feed papers of varied sizes
			- Duplexing assemblyThe duplexing assembly flips the paper over so that you can print on both sides
			  
				- It is not found in all inkjet printers.
			- Carriage beltThe carriage holds the print heads and gets moved into position so the print heads can eject the ink onto the proper spot on the paper
			  
				- The belt moves the carriage into position so the print heads can eject the ink onto the proper spot on the paper
		- #### Calibration
		  
			- Calibration is done to keep the page image sharp and accurate
			- This may be done on a periodic basis and when parts are replaced
			- The printer should be calibrated whenever a print head or ink cartridge is replaced
			- Each printer will have its own calibration process
		- #### Maintenance
			- Inkjet printers require minimal maintenance, which is easily done using features available through the printers menus or software
				- To determine if maintenance is needed, test pages specifically designed to point out flaws can be printed from the printers menus or software
			- Clean headsPrinter heads can get clogged over time. Cleaning the heads can be done by selecting a menu option or through the printers software
			  
				- When initiated, the printer will run through a head-cleaning process
			- Replace cartridgesWhen the ink in a cartridge has been used up, the cartridge must be replaced
			  
				- A calibration should be done after replacing a cartridge
			- CalibrateCalibration is done to keep the page image sharp and accurate
			  
				- This may be done on a periodic basis and when parts are replaced
				- The printer should be calibrated whenever a print head or ink cartridge is replaced
				- Each printer will have its own calibration process
			- Clear jamsPaper may get jammed in the printer as it is fed through
				- It may be cleared manually by simply pulling it out
				- Some printers provide a way to run just the feeder, either manually by turning a wheel or by running the feed motor

		- Thermal printers use chemically treated thermal paper that changes color when heated
			- It is the heat, rather than ink, that transfers the image to the paper
			- Thermal printers are simple and inexpensive
			- Common uses are for receipts and shipping labels
			- The image printed is sensitive to light and heat, so it will fade over time
		- #### Imaging Parts
			- Thermal printers have the following specific imaging parts.
			- Feed assemblyThe feed assembly feeds the thermal paper through the printer.
			- Heating elementThe heating element heats specific areas of the thermal paper as it scrolls by
				- The heated areas darken to create the image.
			- #### Special Paper and Heat Sensitivity
			- Thermal paper is chemically treated paper that changes color when heated
			  
				- This makes the print out vulnerable to damage or degradation when exposed to heat
		- #### Maintenance
		  
			- Maintaining thermal printers is simpler than other types of printers
			- There are fewer moving parts and no ink.
			- Replace paperThermal paper comes in rolls of various sizes
				- Replacing the paper is a simple matter of removing the empty roll and inserting the new roll
				- There is a button or wheel that can be used to feed the paper into the printer after the new roll is inserted
			- Clean heating elementThe heating element should be cleaned periodically to ensure proper heat transfer to the paper
			  
				- Isopropyl alcohol is typically used as the cleaning agent
				- Some printers come with a pen or pad to make it easier to access the heating element for cleaning
			- Remove debrisPaper fragments and dust will accumulate in the printer over time
			  
				- This debris should be removed as needed
				- A commonly used method is to blow out the debris with compressed air

		- Impact printers use a matrix of pins to strike an ink ribbon to transfer ink to the paper
			- The most common type is the dot-matrix printers
			- A unique feature of impact printers, as compared to other printers, is that they can print multiple copies simultaneously using carbonless or no carbon required (NCR) paper.
		- #### Imaging Parts
			- Impact printers have the following specific imaging parts.
			- Print headThe print head is a row or rectangular matrix of metal pins
			  
				- The pins that strike the ink ribbon form the character to be printed
			- RibbonThe ribbon holds the ink that is transferred to the paper by the print head during printing.
			- Tractor feedThe tractor feed feeds the paper through the printer.
		- #### Impact Paper
			- Impact paper is simply paper made for impact printers
				- It may come on a roll or as fanfold paper in single-ply, duplicate, or triplicate
					- Duplicate and triplicate paper transfers the image through to all copies simultaneously
		- #### Maintenance
			- There is little maintenance required on impact printers
				- In most printers, these items can all be replaced by the user.
			- Replace ribbonRibbon replacement is usually a simple task
			  
				- The new ribbon should be taut, leaving no slack.
			- Replace print headThe pins in a print head can get bent or broken, so the print head will eventually need to be replaced
			  
				- The print head does get hot due to the friction of rapidly moving parts, so care must be taken to ensure it cools down before touching it
				- It is held in by a lever that must be released to remove the old print head
			- Replace paperPaper replacement requires a bit more effort than in other types of printers
			  
				- The paper has holes along the side that are placed into the tractor feed
				- These must be aligned so that the paper feeds properly
				- Also, since the paper is continuous, as opposed to separate sheets, the top of the page must be lined up properly

		- A 3D printer is not technically a printer but a fabrication machine through a process called additive manufacturing
		- A three-dimensional object is created by adding layers of filament or liquid resin on top of one another to produce a specified output
		- #### Filament
			- Filament is a plastic substance used by 3D printers to create an object
			- A 3D filament printers components include the frame, the printing plate or print bed, the extruder, the cooling fan, the printed circuit board (PCB), and the filament
			- Filament comes on a spool
			- The main three things to consider when choosing a filament type are the size, type, and color
		- #### Resin
			- Resin is a liquid substance contained in a reservoir used to build a specified object
			- The resin is hardened by a UV light layer by layer to create the object to as stereolithography/digital light processing printers (SLA/DLP)
		- #### Print Bed
			- The print bed is the plate on which the object will be printed
			- In a filament printer, the print bed is located at the bottom of the printer with the printer creating the object from the bottom up
			- The print bed on a resin printer is often located at the top of the printer with the printer creating the object from the top down, appearing to rise from the printer.

item.title: Hardware & Network Troubleshooting
item.description:
General Information

- When hardware and networks work well, its a beautiful thing
- But we know this is not always the case and, as an IT support professional, you will be depended upon to fix whatever goes wrong
- Any device or network issue will fall within your domain
- This is why hardware and network troubleshooting is the most emphasized area on the CompTIA A+ 1101 test, with 29% (nearly one-third) of the questions pertaining to it
- It is important to note that *all* the questions about hardware and network troubleshooting will begin with a scenario

  • [[Best Practice Methodology]]

    • Best practice methodology refers to the use of basic structured principles that should be followed when approaching a troubleshooting situation

item.title: Mobile Devices
item.description:
General Information

- The purpose of assessing your knowledge and skills in this area is to be sure you know how to configure and install all types of mobile devices, including, but not limited to, laptops
- This does not stop after the installation and configuration are complete, however
- You must also be able to ensure continued connectivity for the end-users
- Approximately **15%** of the questions on the **CompTIA A+ Core Series 1101 test** pertain to mobile device concepts
- Note that approximately **75%** of these questions will begin with a **scenario**

  • [[Laptop Hardware and Components]]

    • You must be able to install and configure the hardware and components of a laptop in a given scenario

item.title: Networking
item.description:
General Information

- Understanding all types of networks and their corresponding connections is vital if you are in an IT support position
- You will need to know everything about TCP/IP, Wi-Fi, and SOHO connections
- About 20% of the CompTIA A+ 1101 test concerns various aspects of networking
- Around 25% of the questions concerning networking will begin with a scenario.

  • [[Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP) Ports]]

    • For the CompTIA A+ exam, you must be able to compare and contrast TCP and UDP ports and protocols and their respective purposes

    • Memorizing port numbers #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:00.589Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:00.590Z card-last-score:: 5
      • Highly recommended for this section.

    • Ports and Protocols #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.46 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:38:10.203Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:38:10.203Z card-last-score:: 3
      • For this exam, you should know the following TCP/UDP port numbers, the protocols that run over those ports, and the primary use for each
      • A port is the unique identifier number for transmission control and direction
      • A protocol is a set of rules that govern communications.

      • File Transfer Protocol (FTP) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:13:36.625Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:13:36.625Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • File Transfer Protocol (FTP) is used to manipulate files
        • FTP can copy files, list and manipulate directories, and view file contents
        • FTP runs on ports 20 and 21
        • Port 21 is mainly used for file management and port 20 is used for data transfer
        • FTP is not secure and transmits in plain text.

      • Secure Shell (SSH) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-27T19:33:46.426Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:33:46.427Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Secure Shell (SSH) is a connection-oriented protocol used to set up secure Telnet connections for remote logins
        • SSH is secure and runs on port 22.

      • Telnet #card

        card-last-interval:: -1 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-24T04:00:00.000Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:35:11.559Z card-last-score:: 1 collapsed:: true
        • Telnet is a terminal emulation program that allows for remote access to text on another computer
        • Telnet is not secure and transmits plaintext
        • Telnet uses port 23.

      • Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:05.798Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:05.799Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) is used to send email only and is a push protocol
        • SMTP uses port 25.

      • Domain Name System (DNS) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:13.111Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:13.112Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • The Domain Name System (DNS) is used to resolve hostnames to IP addresses and uses port 53.

      • Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) #card

        card-last-interval:: -1 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-24T04:00:00.000Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:33:22.179Z card-last-score:: 1 collapsed:: true
        • Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) assigns IP addresses dynamically to network clients
        • DHCP uses port 67 for the server and port 68 for the client.

      • Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:39:20.689Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:39:20.690Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true
        • Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) manages communications between a web server and a client to view internet content
        • HTTP is not secure and transmits in plain text
        • HTTP uses port 80.

      • Post Office Protocol 3 (POP3) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T19:04:06.174Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T19:04:06.174Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Post Office Protocol 3 (POP3) is used for downloading email
        • POP3 uses port 110.

      • Network Basic Input/Output System (NetBIOS)/NetBIOS over TCP/IP (NetBT) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:37:14.668Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:37:14.669Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Network Basic Input/Output System (NetBIOS) is an API for communication between computers over a network
        • NetBIOS works over OSI layer 4 and needs to work with a layer 5 protocol, namely TCP/IP, to function properly
        • NetBIOS over TCP/IP is called NetBT
        • NetBIOS runs on ports 137/139.

      • Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:39:28.899Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:39:28.899Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) is currently in its fourth version, or IMAP4, and is used for downloading email
        • IMAP4 is secure and runs over port 143.

      • Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) #card

        card-last-interval:: -1 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-24T04:00:00.000Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:33:02.971Z card-last-score:: 1 collapsed:: true
        • Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is used for network management
        • SNMP uses port 161 for sending and receiving requests and port 162 for receiving transmissions from managed devices.

      • Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) #card

        card-last-interval:: -1 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-24T04:00:00.000Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:31:33.224Z card-last-score:: 1 collapsed:: true
        • Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is used for accessing information stored in an information directory
        • LDAP uses port 389.

      • Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:38:56.926Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:38:56.927Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) is the secure version of HTTP
        • HTTPS uses port 443.

      • Server Message Block (SMB)/Common Internet File System (CIFS) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:36:49.167Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:36:49.168Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • Server Message Block (SMB) is primarily a Microsoft protocol used for shared file access
        • Common Internet File System (CIFS) is an enhanced version of SMB
        • SMB/CIFS use port 445.

      • Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) #cards

        card-last-score:: 3 card-repeats:: 2 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:40:57.291Z card-last-interval:: 4 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:40:57.292Z collapsed:: true
        • Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) allows for remote connection to computers
        • RDP uses port 3389.

    • TCP vs. UDP #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T16:57:28.008Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T16:57:28.008Z card-last-score:: 5

      • Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) #card

        card-last-interval:: 10.24 card-repeats:: 3 card-ease-factor:: 2.56 card-next-schedule:: 2024-05-04T00:36:16.555Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:36:16.556Z card-last-score:: 3
        • is a connection-oriented protocol used to send and receive data over a network
        • Before data is sent, a connection is established with the receiving host
        • It is considered a reliable protocol because the receiving host acknowledges that it received the data
        • TCP is used in cases where receiving the proper data is more important than speed

      • User Datagram Protocol (UDP) #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:39:13.280Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:39:13.281Z card-last-score:: 5
        • is a connectionless protocol
        • Data is sent without any assurance that the receiving host is actually receiving the data
        • For that reason, it is considered an unreliable protocol
        • The advantage of UDP over TCP is that it is faster.

      • Connectionless #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-27T19:31:15.220Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:31:15.223Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true
        • Connectionless protocols allow for data to flow without guaranteeing an established connection
        • This allows for faster data flow but does not guarantee reliable data flow
        • UDP is connectionless.

      • DHCP #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:36:33.726Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:36:33.727Z card-last-score:: 3
        • Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is used to dynamically assign IP configuration information to clients through a lease and uses UDP as its transport protocol
        • DHCP runs on port 67/68.

      • TFTP #card

        card-last-interval:: -1 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-24T04:00:00.000Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:34:55.218Z card-last-score:: 1
        • Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) is a faster version of FTP that uses UDP rather than TCP as its transport protocol
        • TFTP uses port 69.

      • Connection-Oriented #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:38:21.124Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:38:21.125Z card-last-score:: 5
        • Connection-oriented communication establishes a set connection before data flow begins between two devices
        • TCP is connection-oriented.

      • HTTPS #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:38:44.220Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:38:44.220Z card-last-score:: 3
        • Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) is a connection-oriented protocol that uses TCP as its transport protocol
        • HTTPS uses port 443.

      • SSH #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.46 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-27T19:33:52.025Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-23T19:33:52.026Z card-last-score:: 3
        • Secure Shell (SSH) is a connection-oriented protocol that uses TCP as its transport protocol
        • SSH uses port 22.

  • [[Common Networking Hardware]]

    • Networking hardware includes the physical components used to achieve network connectivity
    • You must be able to compare and contrast common networking hardware.

    • Routers #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:58:16.047Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:58:16.048Z card-last-score:: 3
      • A router is a device that connects multiple network devices and determines the best path for reaching a specified device using routing tables
      • Routers are OSI Layer 3 devices and make decisions based on logical addresses
      • Key functions of a router include connecting multiple network devices to one another, breaking up broadcast domains, and connecting one LAN to another LAN on a WAN.

    • Switches #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T19:04:15.796Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T19:04:15.796Z card-last-score:: 3
      • A switch is a device that works at OSI Layer 2, examines the header of incoming packets for the MAC address, and forwards the packet to the correct location
      • Switches can be managed or unmanaged.

      • Managed Switch #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-01T17:34:59.834Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-03-28T17:34:59.834Z card-last-score:: 5
        • A managed switch is one that allows for port configuration, traffic management, and traffic monitoring
        • Managed switches offer quality of service (QoS), redundancy, port mirroring, and VLANs.

      • Unmanaged Switch #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:56:37.639Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:56:37.640Z card-last-score:: 5
        • An unmanaged switch does not allow for configuration and passes on all data for a MAC address to its ports.

    • Access Points #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T16:53:57.207Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T16:53:57.208Z card-last-score:: 5
      • An access point is technically any device to which a host can connect in order to access a network
      • Wired access points include hubs and switches
      • However, the term usually refers to a wireless access point (WAP) that allows Wi-Fi devices to connect to a network.

    • Patch Panel #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:44:23.028Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:44:23.028Z card-last-score:: 5
      • A patch panel is a dumb device that is essentially a large rack-mounted HUB whose sole purpose is to connect cables together
      • A dumb device is a device that broadcasts all data coming in through the input port out over all output ports
      • A dumb device, like a patch panel, makes no logical decisions and simply serves as a connection and relay point.

    • Firewall #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:40.526Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:40.526Z card-last-score:: 5
      • A firewall is a security appliance, either hardware or software, that filters network traffic based on a preconfigured set of rules.

    • Power over Ethernet (PoE) #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T15:51:02.046Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T15:51:02.047Z card-last-score:: 5
      • Power over Ethernet (PoE) is a technology that delivers power to devices over data lines, such as an ethernet cable, rather than having a separate power cord.

      • POE Injectors #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.46 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:26.688Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:26.688Z card-last-score:: 5
        • An injector is a midspan device that sits between the switch and the access point and supplies power via an ethernet connection.

      • POE Switch #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.46 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:16.638Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:16.638Z card-last-score:: 5
        • A switch sits in front of the midspan injector device and provides power to the ethernet cable.

      • PoE Standards #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T15:51:30.367Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T15:51:30.367Z card-last-score:: 3
        • PoE standards are the IEEE 802.3 standards that define PoE specifications.
        • PoE- 802.3af-15.4 W WAPs, static surveillance cameras, VoIP phones
        • PoE+- 802.3at-30W alarm systems, PTZ cameras, video IP phones
        • PoE++- 802.3bt (Type 3)-60 W multi-radio WAPs, video conferencing equipment
        • PoE++- 802.3bt (Type 4)-100 W laptops, flat-screen monitors

    • Hub #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:48.375Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:48.375Z card-last-score:: 5
      • A HUB is a dumb Layer 1 device that sends all incoming data to all connected devices as a broadcast
      • Hubs are also known as multiport repeaters.

    • Cable Modem #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.46 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T19:04:39.538Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T19:04:39.538Z card-last-score:: 3
      • A cable modem is a device that connects to a cable line to provide connectivity
      • A cable modem is technically no longer a modem, however, since it does not modulate and demodulate analog signals.

    • Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:31:54.956Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:31:54.956Z card-last-score:: 3
      • A digital subscriber line (DSL) modem provides connectivity via a telephone line.

    • Optical Network Terminal (ONT) #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.22 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:41:33.656Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:41:33.657Z card-last-score:: 3
      • An optical network terminal (ONT) modem is one that provides connectivity via a fiber-optic line.

    • Network Interface Card (NIC) #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:12:41.452Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:12:41.452Z card-last-score:: 5
      • A network interface card (NIC), also known as a network adapter card, is used to provide the physical interface between a computer and the cabling used for connectivity.

    • Software-Defined Networking (SDN) #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:08:14.849Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:08:14.849Z card-last-score:: 5
      • Software-defined networking (SDN) sets up a network virtually via the cloud
      • The SDN replaces the functionality of the router in a network.

  • [[Protocols for Wireless Networking]]

    collapsed:: true
    • You must be able to compare and contrast wireless networking protocols and what they have in common and where they differ.

    • Frequencies #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T14:42:56.566Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T14:42:56.568Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true

      • Frequency #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:37:11.449Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:37:11.450Z card-last-score:: 5
        • The frequency of a wireless protocol refers to the audio range in which the technology broadcasts
        • The two operating frequencies for Wi-Fi are 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz
        • The frequency has an impact on transmission range and data throughput.

      • #card 2.4 GHz #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:54:40.340Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:54:40.341Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true
        • This relatively low frequency (compared with 5 GHz) has a greater transmission range because it passes through objects such as walls and floors better
        • On the negative side, throughput is slower and it is an open frequency range that other devices use
        • Devices like cordless phones and microwave ovens can interfere with it.

      • #card 5 GHz #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T15:52:27.954Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T15:52:27.955Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true
        • At this higher frequency, throughput is faster
        • On the negative side, the transmission range is shorter as the signal is attenuated by objects such as walls and floors.

    • Channels

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:09:56.594Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:09:56.595Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true

      • Wireless Channel info #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:06:54.155Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:06:54.155Z card-last-score:: 3
        • Channels are different frequencies that are used for communications between the end-user device and the wireless access point
        • The 2.4 GHz range has 14 channels, but the top three cannot be used in North America, so the U.S
        • Has 11 available channels
        • Devices will automatically select a channel, but if there seems to be interference, we can manually select another channel
        • The 5 GHz range also has channels, but there is more room in the RF spectrum at that range, so we never have to set those channels.

      • Wireless Channel Regulations #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 2 card-ease-factor:: 2.7 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T19:05:15.171Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T19:05:15.171Z card-last-score:: 5 collapsed:: true
        • The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has defined 14 different 22 MHz communications channels but only allows for the use of the first 11 channels.

      • 2.4 GHz vs. 5 GHz #card

        card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T16:54:16.215Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T16:54:16.216Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
        • There are 25 defined 20 MHz channels at 5 GHz, 24 of which can be used for Wi-Fi communications, while 2.4 GHz only has 14 defined channels, 11 of which can be used.

    • Bluetooth #card

      card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:33:22.272Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:33:22.273Z card-last-score:: 3 collapsed:: true
      • Bluetooth allows devices to communicate over short distances (10 meters) in a personal area network (PAN)
      • It is typically used to connect peripherals, such as headphones, to a laptop or smartphone
      • It is the IEEE 802.15.1 standard.

    • 802.11 #card

      collapsed:: true card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:55:54.673Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:55:54.673Z card-last-score:: 5

      • 802.11 WiFi Spec #card

        collapsed:: true card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T18:01:18.549Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T18:01:18.550Z card-last-score:: 5
        • The Wi-Fi specification 802.11 is part of the IEEE 802 wireless networking standards
        • It is used for Wi-Fi communications
        • They all use the ethernet protocol and carrier sense multiple access with collision avoidance (CSMA/CA) media access method
        • The main characteristics that differentiate them are their operating frequencies, theoretical maximum data speed, and throughput.

        • 802.11a #card

          • 5 GHz frequency, 54 Mbps maximum throughput, 120 meters range

        • 802.11b #card

          collapsed:: true card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.36 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T17:37:00.505Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T17:37:00.506Z card-last-score:: 3

        • 802.11g #card

          collapsed:: true card-last-interval:: 4 card-repeats:: 1 card-ease-factor:: 2.6 card-next-schedule:: 2024-04-05T14:50:43.928Z card-last-reviewed:: 2024-04-01T14:50:43.929Z card-last-score:: 5
          • 2.4 GHz frequency, 54 Mbps maximum throughput, 140 meters range
